title: South Africa: How the Iranian Nuke Deal Could Affect SA
text:
South Africa: Tutu Hospitalisation Makes News Around the World 
2. Big business in Iran 
With sanctions lifted, South African companies that have invested in Iran would be able to operate with greater ease and so make more profits. MTN for example, which owns 49% of the country's second largest mobile phone operator IranCell, recently said that could stand to repatriate up to $1-billion in loan repayments from Iran if a deal is struck. 
3. The arms industry 
The country's arms industry could also benefit if SA is able to sell military equipment to the Iranian army, which is the fifth most powerful in the Middle East. Growth for SA industries could to further job creation. 
4. Foreign investment in SA 
Iran has a sound economy, though one that's been troubled by sanctions. Ending sanctions could help Iran's economy stabilise - good news for them but potentially bad news for us, according to Deen, who believes this could prompt an outflow of foreign investments from South Africa. "Companies looking to invest in South Africa would rather invest in Iran, because Iran has a more wide economic development and infrastructure. 
5. South Africa's diplomatic stance 
South Africa has long backed Iran's right to harness nuclear energy for peaceful purposes but, if the leaked spy cables are anything to go by, the country was still pressured by the US into keeping an eye on suspected Iranian agents in the country. Independent analyst Tom Wheeler however, says SA's relations with the US will be unaffected by the deal because there's no reason for it to disagree with current negotiations. 
6.Relations with Israel 
Israel, which is rumoured to have a nuclear weapons programme of its own, has vehemently opposed the negotiations and prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu described the deal as "a bad mistake of historic proportions". SA's support for the negotiations however aren't likely to disrupt its ties with Israel. "It's a fairly fraught relationship anyway," Wheeler said. 
While the deal does not necessarily mean Iran will suddenly be embraced by the world, Deen said, the easing of sanctions would mean more economic and political stability for Iran, and in the long run, a more sustainable and peaceful Middle East.
